title: Cannot load a saved torch.jit.trace using C++'s torch::jit::load
body_html:
🐛 Bug

I saved a model in PyTorch python using torch.jit.save. I tried to load the model in C++ using torch::jit::load("model.pt"); but it produced the following error.

To Reproduce

Follow the tutorial here: https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

  1. Converting a torch model via tracing
  2. Serializing the model
  3. Loading the script module in C++

Error Message

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'c10::Error'
what(): read_bytes == 8 ASSERT FAILED at /pytorch/caffe2/serialize/inline_container.h:182, please report a bug to PyTorch. Expected to read 8 bytes but got %llu bytes0 (read64BitIntegerLittleEndian at /pytorch/caffe2/serialize/inline_container.h:182)
frame #0: std::function<std::string ()>::operator()() const + 0x11 (0x7f39eaf7ecd1 in //libtorch/lib/libc10.so)
frame #1: c10::Error::Error(c10::SourceLocation, std::string const&) + 0x2a (0x7f39eaf7e59a in //libtorch/lib/libc10.so)
frame #2: + 0x58df5b (0x7f39f478ff5b in //libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #3: + 0x58ecc5 (0x7f39f4790cc5 in //libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #4: + 0x58f0e3 (0x7f39f47910e3 in //libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #5: + 0x58c41d (0x7f39f478e41d in //libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #6: torch::jit::load(std::istream&) + 0xb4 (0x7f39f478f5d4 in //libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #7: torch::jit::load(std::string const&) + 0x27 (0x7f39f478f6a7 in //libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #8: main + 0x68 (0x40125b in ./mnist)
frame #9: __libc_start_main + 0xf0 (0x7f39eb1aa830 in /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6)
frame #10: _start + 0x29 (0x401089 in ./mnist)

Aborted (core dumped)

Expected behavior

https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#step-4-executing-the-script-module-in-c

Environment

Please copy and paste the output from our
environment collection script
(or fill out the checklist below manually).

You can get the script and run it with:

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py
# For security purposes, please check the contents of collect_env.py before running it.
python collect_env.py

Collecting environment information...

Is debug build: No
CUDA used to build PyTorch: 9.0.176

OS: Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
GCC version: (Ubuntu 5.4.0-6ubuntu1~16.04.6) 5.4.0 20160609
CMake version: version 3.5.1

Python version: 3.6
Is CUDA available: Yes
CUDA runtime version: 9.0.176
GPU models and configuration:
GPU 0: TITAN Xp
GPU 1: Quadro M2000

Nvidia driver version: 384.130
cuDNN version: Probably one of the following:
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcudnn.so.7.0.5

Versions of relevant libraries:
[pip] numpy (1.14.5)
[pip] torch (1.0.0.dev20181029)
[pip] torch-vision (0.1.6.dev0)
[pip] torchvision (0.2.1)
[conda] cuda90 1.0 h6433d27_0 pytorch

[conda] torch 0.3.0.post4
[conda] torch 0.4.1

[conda] torchvision 0.2.1 py36_1 pytorch

🐛 Bug

I saved a model in PyTorch python using torch.jit.save. I tried to load the model in C++ using    torch::jit::load("model.pt"); but it produced the following error.
To Reproduce
Follow the tutorial here: https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html

Serializing the model
Loading the script module in C++

body:
## 🐛 Bug

<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
I saved a model in PyTorch python using torch.jit.save. I tried to load the model in C++ using    torch::jit::load("model.pt"); but it produced the following error.

## To Reproduce
Follow the tutorial here: https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. [Converting a torch model via tracing](https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#converting-to-torch-script-via-tracing)
2. [Serializing the model](https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#step-2-serializing-your-script-module-to-a-file)
3. [Loading the script module in C++](https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#step-3-loading-your-script-module-in-c)

## Error Message 
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'c10::Error'
  what():  read_bytes == 8 ASSERT FAILED at /pytorch/caffe2/serialize/inline_container.h:182, **please report a bug to PyTorch**. Expected to read 8 bytes but got %llu bytes0 (read64BitIntegerLittleEndian at /pytorch/caffe2/serialize/inline_container.h:182)
frame #0: std::function<std::string ()>::operator()() const + 0x11 (0x7f39eaf7ecd1 in /**/libtorch/lib/libc10.so)
frame #1: c10::Error::Error(c10::SourceLocation, std::string const&) + 0x2a (0x7f39eaf7e59a in /**/libtorch/lib/libc10.so)
frame #2: <unknown function> + 0x58df5b (0x7f39f478ff5b in /**/libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #3: <unknown function> + 0x58ecc5 (0x7f39f4790cc5 in /**/libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #4: <unknown function> + 0x58f0e3 (0x7f39f47910e3 in /**/libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #5: <unknown function> + 0x58c41d (0x7f39f478e41d in /**/libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #6: torch::jit::load(std::istream&) + 0xb4 (0x7f39f478f5d4 in /**/libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #7: torch::jit::load(std::string const&) + 0x27 (0x7f39f478f6a7 in /**/libtorch/lib/libtorch.so.1)
frame #8: main + 0x68 (0x40125b in ./mnist)
frame #9: __libc_start_main + 0xf0 (0x7f39eb1aa830 in /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6)
frame #10: _start + 0x29 (0x401089 in ./mnist)

Aborted (core dumped)

## Expected behavior

https://shiftlab.github.io/pytorch_tutorials/advanced/cpp_export.html#step-4-executing-the-script-module-in-c

## Environment

Please copy and paste the output from our
[environment collection script](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py)
(or fill out the checklist below manually).

You can get the script and run it with:
```
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py
# For security purposes, please check the contents of collect_env.py before running it.
python collect_env.py
```
